titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V. Sunday.

lg.l: His hand the beast of prey sustains
The raven’s cry—with food requites
The strength of horses he disdains
Nor in the feat of man delights.
He joys in all who keep his word
Hope for his Mercy—fear his rod
Jerusalem—praise thou the Lord!
And thou, O Zion—praise thy God.
He strengthens of thy gates the bars
Thy children, boundless blessings great
Thy borders, are preserv’d from Wars
He fills thee with the finest wheat.
Forth over Earth his orders go—
His word with speed transcendent flies—
Like flakes of wool he scatters snow
Like ashes spread his hoar-frost lies.

div.p: Heard Mr Smith from Acts 9.6. Lord, what wilt thou have me to do.

Ferdinand Rodolph Hassler; with proof Sheets of his Report on the comparison of Custom-House Weights and Measures. Afternoon Service— Sermon begun before I got to Church— Ride, in the Evening with John and Mary. round the woods— Reminiscences. W. Slade here this Evening. Conversation upon the documents relating to the Treaty with Turkey Several of the papers suppressed— Slade voted against the Tariff-bill, but told me that if the passage of the Bill had depended upon his vote, he would have voted for it— So Ellsworth.
2. V. Monday

lg.l: His ice, like Morsels forth he casts—
And who, before his cold can stand?
He melts them with his scorching blasts
The waters flow at his command.
To Jacob are his judgments known.
No other Nation hears his word.
His Laws, to Israel’s race alone
Their blessings yield— Praise ye the Lord.

div.p: Psalm 148.

lg.l: Praise ye the Lord— In Heaven on high,
Ye Angels praise the God Ministers of Love
Praise him ye armies of the Sky
Praise him, all ye his hosts above.
Praise him, Sun, Moon and Stars that glow,
Ye Heavens of Heavens, his praise proclaim.
Ye Waters oer the Heavens that flow
O let them praise Jehovah’s name

div.p: H.R.U.S— Petition day— None presented— I moved for the printing of 5000 copies. of the Secy of the Treasury & Hassler’s Reports on Weights and Measures. agreed to. Bank U.S. Bill— I went into the Senate, and gave Webster papers relating to the Tariff-Bill. Clay said that P.U.S. would veto the fast-day Resolution, and wished me to move a Resolution by the two Houses—recommending it— Senate’s Committee of Manufactures restore the Minimum’s Return to H.R.U.S. Hoffman attacked me in my absence— Bank-Bill amendments 15 or 20 taken by yeas and nays. Previous question failed— Adjourned near 9. P.M.
3. V. Tuesday.

lg.l: By his commandment they were made,
And through eternity shall last
His Laws by them, shall be obey’d
Till endless ages shall be past.
Praise him ye dwellers upon Earth
Praise him ye Monsters of the deep
Fire—Hail—Snow—Vapours ring with mirth
Ye Tempests, oer the waves that sweep
Ye Hills and Mountains— Brake and glen
Fruit trees and Cedars, hail your king.
Beasts of the forest and the pen
Ye creeping tribes— Ye birds of wing
Kings of the Nations, People, all
Princes and Judges of the Earth.
Young men, and maidens, prostrate fall
Old men and children, shout your mirth

div.p: H.R.U.S. Rule respecting the Previous Question— Motion to alter it debated— Bank-Bill Previous Question— Call of the House— Engrossed for third reading— Rule suspended. Previous Question— Bill passed 106 to 84. Senate immediately concurred in the Amendment— Bill for distributing the proceeds of the public Lands— Motion to postpone till the first Monday in December— Petulant debate. Motion lost by a bare majority to be reconsidered to-morrow. I asked the Speaker not to appoint me on the Prayer Resolution Committee, and he promised he would not— Adjourned about 5. P.M— Ride with John and Mary after dinner— Peyton Gay here this morning with a Mr Chamberland.
4. V. Wednesday— Independence.

lg.l: Yes—let them praise Jehovah’s name
His name is excellent alone
Above the Heavens his praise proclaim
Make above Earth, his glory Sun own.
He shall exalt his People’s power
Let all his Saints, his praise record
Exhaustless blessings he shall shower
On Israel’s race— Praise ye the Lord.

div.p: Psalm 150.

lg.l: Praise ye the Lord— Jehovah praise
Your voices in his temple raise
Extol his Mighty deeds
Who made the firmament on high
Creator of the Earth and Sky—
God—from whom all proceeds
Praise him with trumpet harp and lute
Praise him with timbrel, dance and flute
His praise with Song record—
From Cymbals let his praise rebound
And all that breathes on Earth resound
His name Praise ye the Lord—

div.p: Fahrenheit 92. H.R.U.S. Reconsideration moved of the postponement yesterday of the Land-Bill—refused by an increased majority— Sundry Bills called up— Sundry motions for adjournment. failed. In Committee of the whole on sundry revolutionary pensioner bills— I went into the Senate— They were debating the second harbour Bill from the House. The President has signed the first— Clay’s exultations. Total dereliction of the President, by his supporters— Miller of S.C. His proposed Amendment countenanced by Clay—harbour bill passed— I walked home— R. Rush. D. Webster, C. F. Mercer J. Reed and J. G. Watmough dined with me— Evening conversation with Rush— N. Biddle went for home— Cholera at New-York.
[symbols]
5. V. Thursday.

My poetical labours are closed—perhaps it were best, forever— I am now engaged upon another task. [symbols] H.R.U.S. Fahrenheit at 90— Depressed in Spirit’s— Drayton makes a whitewashing Report for J. H. Eaton and Saml. Houston— Counter-report by Stanberry and I. C. Bates third Report by J. L. Kerr— Quarantine Bill, and perhaps 30 others passed. Resolution for a Cholera fast—3d. reading— Bates of Maine moves to lay it on the Table—refused— Bell moves to recommit with Instructions to alter the Resolution and make the recommendation of the fast to go from the two Houses of Congress themselves— Warm debate— Bell, Plummer Jenifer, Dearborn, Coulter—Briggs—Burges— Letter from P.U.S. to consistory of the Dutch Church read and alluded to— L. Williams, objects to the reference as out of order— Polk as Speaker decides that it is in order—from which decision I appeal— Speight moves to adjourn at 5. P.M— Carried by Yeas and Nays— Walk home— Violent attacks upon me in the Boston Courier and in the Richmond Enquirer. Dearborn shewed me a Letter he had written to J. T. Buckingham.
6. V. Friday.

Meeting of Committee on the Blue Book— E. Whittlesey and J. W. Taylor there— Whittlesey had his Report prepared, to which he we agreed. H.R.U.S.— Day for private Bills— Motion to suspend the rule and take up the second Harbour-Bill, rejected— Sundry private bills passed. Mr Ihrie of Pennsylvania brought me a Letter, from a friend of his suggesting Amendments to the Tariff-Bill— I went into the Senate, and heard the debates on the Amendments to the Tariff-Bill reported by their Committee on Manufactures— The first great struggle was for the Woollen Minimums Clay and Webster made their great concerted effort to carry them— Answered by Hayne, Tazewell—S. Smith, and Benton—Chambers apologized for voting against the Minimums—Frelinghuysen said they were odious—Dallas, Wilkins and Dudley voted for them—Marcy against them—rejected 24 to 23. The whole Amendment rejected— Other amendments carried and some rejected 24 and 24. By casting vote of Vice-President— Motion to raise Woollen manufactures from 50 to 60 per Cent ad valorem failed— Then Webster moved 57 per Cent, which was carried— Tipton of Indiana turning the Scale. I came home about 6. P.M. leaving the Senate still in Session— The House had adjourned before 3. for want of a Quorum—
7. V. Saturday—

Fahrenheit at 95. H.R.U.S— Day for private business— Motion to suspend the rule rejected— Committee of the whole, Wickliffe in the Chair—about 30 private bills passed— Bill for personal Representatives of John Laurens debated—Root—Burges—Bill passed— The weather was so oppressively warm that I could neither write nor remain in my Seat— House adjourned after 4 PM— Senate engaged upon the Tariff-Bill—took a recess from 3 to 5.— Bank veto-message expected all day, but did not come— Watmough told me that he had been posted by Reuben M Whitney— Van Buren and the Cholera reached New-York about the same time— I visited the Library and examined Hume’s account of Charles the first’s demand for the five members of the House of Commons—Hambden, Pym, Hazlerig, Hollis and Strode— Came home and dined alone at six— But the heat of the Evening made it impracticable to write or to endure the flame of a lamp— Letter from my wife to John— His daughter Louisa is in distressing ill-health with a disease in the eyes— So is he himself—
8. V. Sunday. Fahrenheit 94— Thundergust

Bath with John this Morning in the Potowmack.— Heard Mr Smith from Romans 15.6. [“]That ye may with one mind, and one mouth glorify God, even the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ”— Heat insupportable— Visit from James Brown and a young Ingersoll— Bank Veto Message in Suspense— Almost disabled from writing. Heard Smith again in the afternoon; from Joshua 24.19. And Joshua said unto the People, Ye cannot serve the Lord: for he is an holy God: he is a jealous God: he will not forgive your transgressions nor your sins— There is too much sameness in all Mr Smith’s discourses— After a day of tremendous heat there was this Evening a heavy Thundergust. Struck Jos. M. White’s house on Capitol Hill— Received a Note from Mr Webster returning my bundle of Papers relating to the Tariff-bill, with a Note— The Bill passed to the third reading last Evening in Senate by a Majority of 31 to 15.— I am still under deep anxieties concerning it— John S. Barbour told me that the only reason for his voting against it was that he found it a Van Buren Bill—
9. V. Monday.

H.R.U.S— The Resolution for the appointment of a day of prayer on account of the Cholera, was debated. I finally withdrew my appeal from the decision of the Speaker, who by an artifice of form evaded the direct question I had made— Stanbery reflected upon the Speaker more directly— Bell’s motion to recommit and amend the Resolution prevailed— Tariff-Bill came from the Senate with Amendments. I moved their reference to the Committee of Manufactures— They were referred to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union— Foster moves to suspend the Rules to move a Resolution of censure upon Stanbery for his charge against the Speaker—nearly carried— Recess from 3 to half past four O’Clock— Dined with J. W. Taylor— Sent an excuse to Mr Clay afternoon Session— Committee of the whole on the State of the Union Amendments of the Senate to the Tariff Bill, passed through Committee of the whole—some agreed, others disagreed to—reported to the House. Adjourned at 8. PM— Went to Mr Clay’s— Found him and his company at the dessert— Mr Rush came home with me. Conversation with him—
10. V. Tuesday.

H.R.U.S— Found the house in Session, debating the Resolution proposed by Foster of Georgia, to censure Stanbery for charging the Speaker with shaping his course, to obtain office by seeking favour at the Palace— Question of order depending—Clay of Alabama in the Chair. Stanbery’s words were not taken down when spoken—Clay decided that the motion for censure was in order—Mercer appealed and the question of order was debated till the orders of the day were called for and carried by yeas and nays— Tariff Bill, Amendments of the Senate Report from Committee of the whole debated in the House— The principal Amendments were disagreed to Drayton’s Motion renewed. Speaker declares it in order— Bullard appeals— Decision of the Speaker reversed by the House 81 to 78— Previous Question excluded me from speaking on the increase by Amendment of the Senate from 50 to 57 per Cent duty on high priced woollens— House adjourned at 5. P.M— The President’s negative on the Bank-Charter Bill was sent this Morning to the Senate— M. Van Buren arrived here Sunday Evening and lodges at the Presidents— Was in the house this morning Garsed and a Mr Brown here this Morning— Andrew Armstrong this eve.
11. V. Wednesday— 65 years of age.

H.R.U.S. House’s Resolu in Session— Foster’s Resolution of charges upon Stanbery, debated—I spoke against it—Stanbery moves that Clay leave the Chair—Words taken down—Polk’s motion—words and conduct— Speaker Stevenson takes the chair—debate goes back to Foster’s Resolution—Previous Question carried— On my names being called I asked to be excused from voting for reasons assigned in writing. House refused—My name called again—I declined voting—Motion to reconsider the vote refusing to excuse me. Taken by yeas and nays—House refuse to reconsider—I still decline voting—Some confusion— Drayton moves two Resolutions—1 charging me with violating a Rule of the House—2 A Committee to enquire what is to be done— After some debate consideration of these motions postponed— Question on Foster’s Resolution by yeas and nays carried— Bullard—Daniel—Nuckolls— I moved a Committee to meet Committee of Conference from the Senate on the Tariff-Bill— Archer objects to my being on the Committee—I assent—but insist that the Committee of the House like that of the Senate should be of members on both sides— Adjourned before 3. P.M— I went into Speaker Stevenson’s chamber, and told him there would appear in the National Intelligencer to-morrow morning a Letter from me to him; written in consequence of the publication with his authority of a Letter from Mr Madison to him; and which Letter the publisher affirms overthrows the heresy contained in my Report from the Committee of Manufactures— He seemed a little nettled at this notice—professed great respect for me, but admitted that he had furnished this Letter of Mr Madison’s to Ritchie at his request to refute the doctrines of my Report— Stevenson always disclaims intentions while he admits the facts which prove them— He was now very full of professions of respect for which I thanked him— I came home, and found a Letter from my Son Charles to his brother—distressing by the account of the disease of Louisa’s eyes— Her father’s eyes are also much affected— I wrote a short Letter to my wife— I commence the sixty-sixth year of my life in great distress of mind
12. V. Thursday.

My Letter to Andrew Stevenson, Speaker of the House of Representatives of the United States, was published in the National Intelligencer.— I went to the Capitol, shortly before the Meeting of the House, to see that the Journal of yesterday’s proceedings in the House, should be correct— There was one error which I pointed out to the Clerk, and which he corrected— H.R.U.S. Drayton’s two Resolutions against me were soon taken up— Motion by Edward Everett, to lay them on the table—rejected 59 to 63. Motion of C. F. Mercer to postpone them to 1. September—not put. Motion of J. W. Taylor to postpone them till next Monday—debated— I charged Drayton himself with violation of Rule 20. in making his charge against me yesterday from another seat than his own— The Speaker instantly decided contrary to the Rule, that Drayton had been in order— Drayton began to speak and soon got out of Order— I called him to order, and the Speaker decided that he was out of Order— M’Duffie moved that the two Resolutions should be referred to a Committee, to which I objected— Wayne moved they should be laid on the table Carried—Much miscellaneous business then quietly transacted House adjourned at 6. P.M— Mr Frye part of the Evening here— Mary dined at her Uncle Johnson’s. L. M’Lane called me out in the house— Said Mr Clay had notice that the Tariff Resolution calling for a plan was in M’Lane’s handwriting.
13. V. Friday.

H.R.U.S. I presented a Petition from Hume Bell, offering to sell a Secret for curing the Cholera, for 100000 dollars— Laid on the table— Offered a Resolution, for a new Rule for transacting business in the House—about words spoken in debate— To lay over one day— Everett offers a Resolution for purchasing copies of Elliot’s Debates and Illustrations of the Constitution— Lays over a day— Motion to suspend the rule for transacting private business this day and to-morrow—lost— Great number of private Bills acted upon.— Senate receded from their disagreements and agreed to the Amendments of the House to theirs— Bill has thus passed both houses— Senate announced the veto of the President upon the Bank-Bill— House sat till 3. P.M. Then took a recess till 5— I walked home. House met at five and sat till 8— Private Bills—a number passed—several rejected— Rebecca Blodget’s Bill passed— Candles lighted. No Quorum— Adjourned after 8. P.M— I came home fagged. Mr Chambers, Senator from Maryland gave me a Letter for Mr Frye—which I sent him. He came to the Capitol— Quarrel in the Senate between T. H. Benton and H. Clay.— Letters from my dear wife, and from Charles—Louisa better [symbols]
14. V. Saturday.

Unwell—up in the Night— H.R.U.S. found the House in Session— Difficulty of obtaining a Quorum— Several Resolutions laid on the table— Mine for the additional rule— Cambreleng’s to print 10.000 copies of the Bank Veto-Message. Whittlesey’s motion to add to it so much of the Annual Report of the Secretary of the Treasury on the finances as relates to the Bank— Debate thereon laid on the Table. Bill for allowing interest to the States— Polk moves twice to lay the Bill on the Table—fails. Bill carried 75 to 35.— Potowmac Bridge Bill carried. Recess from 1/4 past 2 till 5.— Home and dined— Met again at 5. Calls of the House an hour to get a bare Quorum— Tariff-Bill signed. Resolution to recommend a day of prayer laid on the Table— Dearborn’s Resolution asking for Instructions to Downes and his despatches upon his War, with the Malays of Sumatra— Message with the papers called for. Hoffman moves that the Instructions be printed—debate—laid on the Table— Recess from 1/2 past 6. to 8. P.M. Meeting by Candle-light. About 9. adjourned to 6. A.M. Monday.
15. V:15. Sunday.

Unwell. Up again in the Night— Swell after a Storm— Rolling of the Ship— Heard Smith from Romans 1.8. First, I thank my God through Jesus Christ for you all, that your faith is spoken of throughout the world— He read extracts from a pastoral Letter of the Assembly of the Presbyterian Church; upon the late revivals— P. R. Fendall here.— Time consumed in assorting papers— Heard Mr Smith in the afternoon, from 2. Chronicles 32.10. [“]Thus saith Sennacherib King of Assyria, Where on do ye trust, that ye abide in the siege in Jerusalem”— Mr Smith said the People might have answered that their trust was in God— This Evening I rode with John and Mary round by the Navy-yard and Eastern-branch Bridge— This ride I used to take on horseback three or four times a week in the spring, Summer, and Autumn of 1828. I have scarcely been there since— I am beginning my preparations for departure— Mrs Tudor with her Grand daughter Delia Stewart were here in the Evening— Mrs Tudor spoke of the Elegy upon Pynsent, of which she said all the copies in this Country were from one taken by her husband before the revolutionary War. She says Delia writes verses.
16. V. Monday.

H.R.U.S. Close of the first Session of the 22d. Congress— House met at 6. A.M— Between 60 and 70 Members present— No Quorum, but no count. Mr Post made a short and appropriate prayer— Two or three Bills received from the President— Gratuities to the Officers of the House M’Duffie renewed the motion to print 10000 copies of the Bank veto message, and E. Whittlesey permitted it to be carried— I moved that 500 extra copies of the Reports on weights and measures be printed. 300 for the Treasury Departments and 200 for Hassler—agreed to. Joint Message to P.U.S. Congress ready to adjourn— Return Message from P.U.S— No further communication to make. Message to and from Senate— House adjourned at 8. P.M.— I returned Books to the Library— Mr and Mrs and Mrs Silsbee left thence for home— In the forenoon I called at the War Office, to ascertain the Balance of pension due to Elijah Bisbe—Cass, Secretary of War, gone. Roberts, Chief Clerk there—met Burd—Elijah Bisbe not a pensioner. Making preparations for departure. E. Wyer, this Morning.
17. V. Tuesday.— From Washington to Baltimore Ezekl. 13

Morning occupied in preparations for departure— At one O’Clock P.M— A Stage Coach of the Line of Stockton and Stokes took us up, my Son John and me, and proceeded to the lodgings of Mr Edward Everett, who had engaged the Carriage for himself and his family, and with whom I had agreed to go— My Son goes to Philadelphia to consult Dr Physick upon the distressing complaint in his eyes— I called at the Treasury Department and made enquiries respecting any balance due to Elijah Bisbe; but his name was not on the Books— Mr. and Mrs. Everett, with their four infant children Ann, Charlotte, Grace Webster and Edward with a nurse, joined us in the Stage, and just at Sunset we alighted at Barnum’s Hotel at Baltimore— Isaac Munroe Editor of the Baltimore Patriot was standing at the door— He gave me a hand bill just published, with accounts from New-York of yesterday Morning 163 new cases of the spasmodic cholera and 86 deaths in the 24 hours ending Sunday Noon—5. cases yesterday at Philadelphia— I had two or three visitors in the course of the Evening, among them Mr Jenifer of the House of Representatives— The Anti-Jackson Meeting at Philadelphia yesterday is said to have been about 7000 in numbers.
18. IV:30. From Baltimore to Philadelphia.— Wednesday.

At six this Morning we took the Steamboat Independence Captain Jeffries, and at eleven landed at the Railway below Frenchtown. Twenty five minutes in passing and conveying our baggage from the Boats to the Cars—one hour and thirty-five Minutes in crossing to Newcastle— At one embarked in the Steam-boat William Penn; and at a quarter before four landed at Chesnut Street wharf Philadelphia. We had as fellow passengers—besides Mr Everett and his family—Mr and Mrs Tomlinson of Connecticut—Mr and Mrs Burges of Rhode-Island—Messrs. Cooper and Hughes of New-Jersey, J. W. Taylor of New-York—Slade of Vermont and Kavenagh of Maine— I had much conversation with Kavenagh, who is a Roman Catholic— Mr Everett and his family took lodgings at the United States Hotel— I came to Mr Nicholas Biddle’s. Met him on the way— Went with him to General Cadwalader’s, where there was a dining party. Count de Survilliers there— He embarks the day after to-morrow for Liverpool; and Genl. Cadwalader is going in the same Ship.— He to return in October— Called as we were returning to Mr Biddle’s at Judge Hopkinson’s where we saw Mrs Hopkinson and Miss Mease.
19. IV:45. Thursday.

Reading, W. L. Stone’s Letters on Masonry and Anti-Masonry—and Mitchell’s Translation of Aristophanes— Went with Mr Biddle to the Bank— New-York Papers— Steamboats go from Jersey City to Summerset on Taunton river— Call on E. Everett at U.S. Hotel—goes to morrow. Call at J. Sargeant’s— At Church— Day of Humiliation and Prayer. Heard Mr Barnes— At Sergeant’s afterwards— Returned to Mr Biddle’s. Letter to my wife—to J. Vaughan with A. Armstrong’s Peruvian Minerals for American Philosophical Society— Dined at Dr Chapmans— Count de Survilliers there— He told me his objects in going to Europe. To settle his private affairs—to visit his mother and family—and perhaps to be the regent of France, if his nephew the Duke of Reichstadt should be called to be king of France— He goes pour faire Acte de presence—to be ready if the Holy Alliance, and the People of France unite to call him to the head of affairs to assume the Sovereign— His hopes are however less sangwine than they were— Called again, in the Evening on Mr Everett— He still concludes to go tomorrow Morning. I determined to stay till Saturday— Light Thundergust while we were at dinner— C. J. Ingersoll’s political manifesto’s.
20. V. Friday—

My companions from Washington, all proceeded this day to New-York— I was persuaded to wait till to-morrow— The Count Survilliers and General Cadwalader went down the river and embarked for Liverpool. I called at the Bank, but the directors were in Session— At Mr Duponceau’s, but he was not at home— The heat was so intense that I strolled no further, but commenced a critique on the character and Tragedy of Hamlet— My Son John was very unwell— A small party dined at Mr Biddle’s—Mr James Brown, Dr Chapman, Mr Daniel W. Coxe and Coll Watmough— Much talk on politics— Some upon electioneering— Prospects of National Republicans desperate Never so little political excitement— Attended in the Evening a Meeting of the American Philosophical Society. Mr Duponceau presided— One paper read— One candidate for Membership balloted for and admitted— Weather sultry— Shower— Mr Biddle said the Directors of the Bank were much urged now to take an active part in electioneering; but would inflexibly decline— Well.
21. IV:30. Saturday— From Philadelphia to Hoboken.

At 6. this Morning we embarked— My Son John for Baltimore; returning to Washington—I in the line for New-York. Mr Biddle accompanied me to the boat; and took leave of me at the second Bell, as did also Mr John Vaughan— I was now left to pursue my way home alone— My dear Son John, goes quite unwell— Among my fellow passengers was Coll. Clinch of the Army—who spoke well of Lieutt Robert Buchanan— In the Stage from Trenton to New-Brunswick my fellow-passengers were all men, and total Strangers— Dull Time, and no Conversation— Steam-boat Swan at New-Brunswick. Met on board Mr Phineas L. Tracy, and his wife; she much alarmed at the Cholera— The boat before going to New-York landed us at the Hoboken ferry landing at 5. in the afternoon. We took lodgings at the Hotel kept by Thomas Swift— Many fugitives there from New-York— All the Steam-boats for New-England Ports have suspended their trips— No Stage going to-morrow— Mr Swift sent to New-York and engages passages for us in the Constellation Steam-boat, going up the river to Albany— I propose stopping at Fishkill Landing; and to go thence to Pokeepsie and accross the County to Litchfield, Hartford, and on to Boston and Quincy.
22. V. Sunday— From Hoboken to Cedar Grove— Fishkill landing

The Report of Yesterday at New-York was 311. new cases, and 104 deaths by the Cholera in 24 hours— At ten this Morning with Mr and Mrs Tracy, I went in the ferry Steam-boat Fairy-Queen from Hoboken, and met near the New-York shore the Steam-boat Constellation, going to Albany—we passed from one boat to the other. In the Constellation I found Matthew L. Davis. C. C. Cambreleng and Mr and Mrs J. S. Barrell of Boston— Two or three passengers were landed at West-Point, and at 4 in the afternoon I, and some others landed at Newburgh— The Constellation immediately proceeded for Albany with the rest— I crossed immediately the river in the ferry-boat to Fishkill landing— Mr Daniel Le Roy, a Son of Herman Le Roy, my old friend crossed with me to the landing. He had made himself known to me in the boat— His wife was with him exceedingly ill— A carriage was waiting for them at the landing. I came immediately to Cedar-grove— Mr De Wint was at Church, but soon came home with the Clergyman Mr Turner— Mrs De Wint, my niece received me— I remain here till to-morrow— Mr Le Roy told me that he had lost a Servant by the Cholera— Had a severe attack of the previous symptoms himself, and Mrs Le Roy was ill with them now.
23. V. Monday— From Cedar Grove to Pokeepsie

I rode this Morning with Mr De Wint to the manufacturing establishments of Mr Peter H. Schenk, which I had visited in October 1818. They are now very much enlarged— There was then only a manufacture of coarse Cotton Cloths which is still continued, and the several parts of which we now visited: but there is now a large establishment for making all the machinery used in the Cotton and woollen manufactures—such as wheels and spindles, and other machines of iron and steel—the works all moved by Steam and water power. There is a school also connected with the establishment where we saw about 40 children from 5 to 12 years of age, learning to read write and cypher. The woollen manufacture is about two miles further off and I did not see it— We returned and dined at Mr De Wint’s— Mrs De Wint his mother, and Mr Turner the Unitarian Minister were there— At five in the afternoon, Mr De Wint took me in his Jersey-waggon and pair of horses 15 miles to Pokeepsie— Where we arrived at the dusk of Evening about 8. P.M— His eldest daughter Caroline Elizabeth was with us. We took lodgings at Hatch’s tavern—a very good house, and walked round the town which is beautiful—
24. V. Tuesday— From Pokeepsie to Litchfield 53 miles.

At six this Morning I took the Stage, of the line from Pokeepsie to Litchfield— The road running from— I took leave of Mr De Wint, but his daughter had not risen— We left Pokeepsie with six men three women, one of them with an infant in the stage— Breakfasted at Washington, and dined at Sharon the first town in Connecticut— The Stage house at Amenia was at the corner of the State of New-York. There was but a Liberty Pole between it and Connecticut— At Sharon where we dined two young women left us to go and take refuge at the house of a friend in Salisbury— They were fleeing from the Cholera at New-York— We arrived at Litchfield about 6 in the Evening after passing by the house of the Ex-Governor John Cotton Smith— I walked out to view the Village; a beautiful avenue, shaded with lofty trees, extending about a mile— Met as I was walking a person, who introduced himself to me as Dr Catlin— He walked with me and named to me the dwellers in the houses as we passed along— After my return to the Inn I was visited in the Evening by sixty or seventy person, inhabitants of the town, and among them by the young men of the Law School, kept here 14 in number. but Judge Gould their Teacher was not with them.
25. III.30. Wednesday— From Litchfield to Woodstock— 70 Miles.

At 4 of the morning we departed from Litchfield for Hartford— All my fellow passengers of yesterday save one man had drop’d here and there on the way; others, fewer in number took their places; among them a handsome young woman, with her husband— She was very sick on the way— We breakfasted at Burlington, and reached Morgan’s United States Hotel in Hartford at 1/2 past 11— Here my companions again dispersed, and I took passage in another hire for Boston— It left the Stage office half past Noon, and took up fifteen passengers including six children, five of them with one woman; also a blind old man, and a National Bostonian named Newell— The heat was intense—the dust choaking and powdering— It was four O’Clock when we reached Vernon where we dined— That is Mr Newell and myself.— The woman with 5 children, and another with one had left us— Just as we alighted at Vernon came on a thunder gust, and the rain in torrents fell &c for nearly three hours— Our Stage was afterwards stalled, and drawn out of the mire by two pair of oxen— At Ashford, I was recognized by the old couple where I breakfasted on the 9th: of December 1830— We rode in the dark till ten at Night when we came to Woodstock, and took immediately to bed.
26. IV. Thursday— From Woodstock to Quincy. 62 Miles.

It was nearly half past 4. when Mr Newell and myself the only remains of the overflowing Stage company from Hartford entered the Carriage this Morning— We breakfasted at Sutton, at the house where I supped on the 8th. of December 1830. At Webster a Town newly set off from Northbridge we took in a Boston merchant named Tiffany— Two other passengers, one a young Englishman in the middle of the road; and at Hopkinton my old Classmate Dr T. M. Harris who was leaving his two daughters there for the use of the Springs— At half past 3. we entered Boston over the Western Avenue; just in time for me to take the Quincy Stage at 4.— I landed at my own house at Quincy, just at 6. P.M. and [symbols] found my family all well— My journey from Washington has been altogether pleasing, and although much lengthened by the dreadful Pestilence raging at New-York, has been marked with no disastrous incident. After getting home I dined, and visited my plantation of young trees in the garden— My Son Charles with his wife and infant daughter are here—
27. IV:30. Friday.

I am apprehensive of falling into a state of idleness, having wasted this day without useful occupation— I found several Letters here upon my arrival last Evening, and neglected answering them this day. The mail of this morning brought me a Letter from my Son John, dated at Washington, Sunday Evening the 22d. after his return, but in the hand-writing of his wife— I resumed the reading of the Bible, at Ezekiel Chapter 29.— Also Stone’s Letter to me upon Masonry and Anti-Masonry— And Mitchell’s Aristophanes, with which I compared Madame Dacier’s Translation of the Clouds and Brumoy’s Analysis of the same play in the Theatre des Grecs— Towards Evening I visited Mrs Ann Adams, my brother’s widow, whom I found much distressed— He died on the 12th. of March, leaving me the only Survivor of the family of the first generation from our Parents— Her daughter Mrs Angier was there, confined with a severe cold and cough— Elizabeth is absent on an excursion in Maine with Edward and Mrs Miller— Louisa C Smith was also there. Isaac Hull at West-Point, Joseph Harrod a Midshipman gone to the Mediterranean with Commodore Patterson, John Quincy at School, at Mr Angier’s— Lieutt. Thomas B. stationed in North-Carolina. I called also at Mr John Greenleafs and delivered Letters to Mrs Greenleaf and Mrs G. M. Dawes.
28. V. Saturday.

Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— Morning visit from Mr Peter Whitney our Minister Mr Oliver Billings came to ask advice concerning the Execution of a Will which he was determined to accomplish this day— He had cancelled another Will, made two or three years since, and he told me how he wished to dispose of his Estate; partly to his Son, and partly to a Trustee for the benefit of his daughter; a married woman; and her children— The Trustee whom he selected was Deacon Daniel Spear, and in the Event of his decease or disability, Lemuel Brackitt Esqr. Charles drew up a Will according to these directions, which Mr Billings executed this Evening. Mr Brackitt came with him, but being one of the Trustees named could not sign it as a witness—Charles and his wife witnessed it with me— Benjamin Bass came and paid me a years interest on his note and mortgage of 7. July 1829. payment of principal postponed. I bathed at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s wharf before dinner— Wrote to my Son John— Still idle— Astronomics of Manilius.
29. V. Sunday.

Heard Mr Andrew Bigelow, of Medford, in the Morning from Ephesians 2.8. “For by grace are ye saved through faith”— A Calvinistic text upon which he gave an unitarian commentary; after his usual manner.— In the afternoon, his text was Psalm 37.37. [“]Mark the perfect man, and behold the upright: for the end of that man is peace.”— This was a moral discourse; well written and well reasoned— Mr Bigelow dined with us— And also Louisa C. Smith: proposing to resume the practice of religious reading on Sundays, I read this afternoon the first of three Sermons of Saurin, upon delays of conversion— Saurin was a French protestant preacher, first at London and afterwards at the Hague— His doctrine in this discourse is calvinistic— His method is the same as that of the French Catholic Preachers— President Quincy was at the Meeting, and spoke to me rather discouragingly of my ward—Ward Nicholas Boylston— I spent the Evening with Mrs: Adams, my Son Charles and his wife at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s— Met him and Thomas Greenleaf coming to our house; but they turned back with us. Mr Whitney gave notice at Meeting that the Communion would be administered next Sunday.
30. V:30. Monday.

Deacon Spear came and settled accounts for salt meadow grass standing on the Borland, Cherry-tree and Penny-ferry lots— Paid him a small bill of his brother William for cutting and carting wood— He spoke of my other lots and dwelling houses now occupied by. W. Field and Seth Burrill— Mr Bailey called; going to Weymouth to avouch the amount of specie, in a new Bank located there, for that town and Braintree— He called again after dinner upon his return, with Mr Fiske of Wrentham a member of the Executive Council, and Mr Fisher of Dedham, Cashier of the Dedham Bank, Commissioners with him to perform this service— Mrs Boylston was here this afternoon, and brought a Letter from President Quincy to her Son, about his son—Ward, who has been conditionally matriculated—to have a sort of guardian—graduate or Proctor to room with him the next year— He is idle and boyish, and has no good rank in the Class— Mrs Boylston thinks it best to comply with the condition and I concur in that opinion— Ward is at his fathers at Princeton during the present vacation till the Saturday after Commencement. Charles went to Boston and returned— Evening walk with my wife, who was this day bled in both arms by Dr Woodward.
31. V:30. Tuesday.

I had a slight return of the complaint which had befallen me a few days before I left Washington. Dull and showery day— Mr Solomon Thayer called to tell me of his success with the new species of grain which he has cultivated for the last five years successively— He sowed the 7th. of last September half an acre of Land with it, from which he reaped last week a crop at the rate of ninety bushels to an Acre the grain weighing 34. pounds to a bushel— The grain is much smaller than wheat or Oats but has, he thinks four times as much flour in it as Oats— He has raised now about forty bushels from five spires which five years ago came up unexpectedly with grass of which he had sown the seed— Mr Thayer has a claim for a pension under the Act of the last Session for Revolutionary Service— I gave him a copy of the Act with the Instructions, from the War Department— I wrote three short letters, but am wasting my time, by indulging myself in the luxury of various reading— Collections of the New-York Historical Society and Mitchell’s Translation of the Wasps of Aristophanes— The play from which Racine took his Plaideurs.
